\chapter{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{intro:introduction}}\label{\detokenize{intro::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Infoblox BloxOne suite of applications provides a RESTful API that is
published using Swagger on \sphinxurl{https://csp.infoblox.com/apidoc} along with other
Infoblox APIs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This module aims to provide a class hierarchy to simplify access to these
published APIs, performing the ‘heavy lifting’ whilst providing full access to
to their functionality. This is achieved by providing simple wrappers that enable
you to take the swagger documented object paths, fields and where appropriate
JSON body from the documentation and pass them to simple get, create, delete and
update methods. These methods simply return a \sphinxstyleemphasis{requests} response object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In addition, useful utility methods are provided for common tasks such as
getting an object id, by defining the object key and value match pair. This is
combined with several (currently) undocumented API calls.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Some basic configuration, such a base url, API version and API key are read
from an ini file. An example of which is provided. When instantiating/initialising
this will read config.ini by default. Alternatively a path can be provided.

\sphinxAtStartPar
PyPi:
\sphinxurl{https://pypi.org/project/bloxone/}

\sphinxAtStartPar
GitHub:
\sphinxurl{https://github.com/ccmarris/python-bloxone}

\chapter{Requirements}
\label{\detokenize{requirements:requirements}}\label{\detokenize{requirements::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}} requires Python 3.x and was developed under Python 3.8. As such it is unlikely to work with Python 2.x.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\chapter{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{installation:installation}}\label{\detokenize{installation::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Please ensure you have Python 3 plus the required modules as defined in the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{requirements::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{Requirements}}}} section.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This was developed under Python 3.8 but may work on earlier versions, but
has not been tested. It is suggested a minimum version of 3.6, but may
work with earlier versions.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{important}{Important:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Mac users will need the xcode command line utilities installed to use pip3, etc.
If you need to install these use the command:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} xcode\PYGZhy{}select \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}install
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Installing Python}
\label{\detokenize{installation:installing-python}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can install the latest version of Python 3.x by downloading the appropriate
installer for your system from \sphinxhref{https://python.org}{python.org}.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are running MacOS Catalina (or later) Python 3 comes pre\sphinxhyphen{}installed.
Previous versions only come with Python 2.x by default and you will therefore
need to install Python 3 as above or via Homebrew, Ports, etc.

\sphinxAtStartPar
By default the python command points to Python 2.x, you can check this using
the command:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} python \PYGZhy{}V
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To specifically run Python 3, use the command:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZdl{} python3
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you are installing Python on Windows, be sure to check the box to have
Python added to your PATH if the installer offers such an option
(it’s normally off by default).
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Installing \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}}}
\label{\detokenize{installation:installing-bloxone}}\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Install from PyPI

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}} module is available on PyPI and can simply be installed
using pip/pip3:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{pip3} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{bloxone} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{user}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Intall bloxone as local package from source

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you have downloaded the source from GitHub then \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}} has been
provided as an installable package using pip.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In your appropriate python3 environment you can therefore install \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}}
using the pip command from the root of the sourcetree. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{pip3} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{dist}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{version}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{py3}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{none}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{any}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{whl} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{user}

\PYG{o+ow}{or}

\PYG{n}{pip3} \PYG{n}{install} \PYG{n}{dist}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{version}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tar}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{gz} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{user}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use of pip ensures module dependencies and allows for
uninstallation and upgrades to be handled cleanly.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Uninstalling \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}}}
\label{\detokenize{installation:uninstalling-bloxone}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can use pip to unintsall the library. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{pip3} \PYG{n}{uninstall} \PYG{n}{bloxone}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\chapter{Usage and Examples}
\label{\detokenize{usage:usage-and-examples}}\label{\detokenize{usage::doc}}

\section{Inifile configuration}
\label{\detokenize{usage:inifile-configuration}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A sample inifile for the bloxone module is shared as \sphinxstyleemphasis{bloxone.ini} and follows
the following format provided below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BloxOne}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{url} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{https://csp.infoblox.com}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{api\PYGZus{}version} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{v1}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{api\PYGZus{}key} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}you API Key here\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can therefore simply add your API Key, and this is ready for the bloxone
module used by the automation demo script. Legacy, interactive and service API
keys are supported.


\section{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{usage:overview}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The aim of this module is to provide simple object based access to the
BloxOne APIs and make it as simple as possible to code given the available
swagger documentation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are several classes/subclasses that provide this access. The base
class is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1}}. This acts as a parent class for the BloxOne Application
APIs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The specific API ‘trees’ are then split in to subclasses of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1}}:
\begin{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1ddi}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne DDI API with core methods for \sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create},
\sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} in addition to specific task orientated helper
methods.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1td}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the Infoblox TIDE API with a generic \sphinxstyleemphasis{get} method plus
specific task orientated helper methods.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1tdc}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Threat Defence Cloud API with a generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} methods plus specific task orientated
helper methods.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1tdep}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Threat Defence Cloud API with a generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task
orientated helper methods.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1tddfp}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Threat Defence Cloud API with a generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task orientated helper
methods.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1tdlad}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Threat Defence Cloud API with a generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, method.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1anycast}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Anycast API with a generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1authn}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne On\sphinxhyphen{}Prem Authentication Service API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1bootstrap}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne On\sphinxhyphen{}Prem Bootstrap App API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1cdc}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Data Connector API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1diagnostics}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Allows the user to execute remote commands on an OPH via the API

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1oph}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne On Prem Host API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific tasks
to allow simple status reporting, App control, etc.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1platform}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Methods to provide access to users and audit log information

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1sw}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne Software Upgrade Scheduling API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1ztp}}}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Access to the BloxOne On Prem Host Host Activation API with generic
\sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} methods plus specific task

\end{description}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In addition to the API interfaces a set of data handling functions is provided
in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{utils}} sub\sphinxhyphen{}module.


\section{Basic Usage}
\label{\detokenize{usage:basic-usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using BloxOne DDI as an example, the basic usage structure for a \sphinxstyleemphasis{get} is:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{b1ddi} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{ini} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{object} \PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{return\PYGZus{}codes\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Similarly for the other core functions, and classes. For details on method
specific parameters, please see the {\hyperref[\detokenize{classes::doc}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{doc}{class documentation}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For debugging purposes, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone}} module supports logging using
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{logging}} using DEBUG.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
I have attempted to keep debugging clean, however, there is still potential
for the debug output to produce full data dumps of API responses.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\section{Generic API Wrapper}
\label{\detokenize{usage:generic-api-wrapper}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
It is also possible to use the bloxone.b1 class as a generic API wrapper with public methods
for \sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete}. These can be used to pass a full URL, and where
appropriate body and parameters. It is of course possible to build the URL using the attributes
of this class, in addition to manually entering the full url:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{b1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{b1}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{ini} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{url} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{https://csp.infoblox.com/api/ddi/v1/ipam/ip\PYGZus{}space}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{url}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{json}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{url} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ddi\PYGZus{}url} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/ipam/ip\PYGZus{}space}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{url}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{\PYGZus{}filter}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name==}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{test\PYGZus{}ip\PYGZus{}space}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{json}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{usage:examples}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Although the basic flow of: instantiating the class with a configuration ini
file; access the attributes or methods, with \sphinxstyleemphasis{get} almost being universal
as a method, and using the swagger object paths to access the required
resource. Specific examples for each of the classes, and their use, is shown
in more detail in the following documents, as well as the usage of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{utils}}:


\subsection{Examples for class: b1ddi}
\label{\detokenize{b1ddi-usage:examples-for-class-b1ddi}}\label{\detokenize{b1ddi-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The aim of this class is to provide simple object based access to the
BloxOne DDI API and make it as simple as possible to code given the available
swagger documentation.


\subsubsection{Basic Usage}
\label{\detokenize{b1ddi-usage:basic-usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
For BloxOne DDI therefore the basic usage structure for a \sphinxstyleemphasis{get} is:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{b1ddi} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n}{cini} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}}\PYG{n+nb}{object} \PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{return\PYGZus{}codes\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
With create and update the key difference is that a JSON body is supplied:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{payload} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{address}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{: }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.0.0.0}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{, }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{cidr}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{: }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{24}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ \PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/ipam/subnet}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{body}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{payload}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{repsonse}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{b1ddi}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{return\PYGZus{}codes\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{repsonse}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{status\PYGZus{}code}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{response}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a b1platform object}

\subsection{b1diagnostics Usage}
\label{\detokenize{b1diagnostics-usage:b1diagnostics-usage}}\label{\detokenize{b1diagnostics-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1diagnostics}} provides the ability to run remote commands on
an OPH via the API and download the results.


\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{b1diagnostics-usage:examples}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{\label{\detokenize{b1diagnostics-usage:id1}}Todo:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These are simple examples to show you usage of the class. More comprehensive
documentation is on the todo.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Instantiate class with ini file as argument}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Show remote commands and args}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Check a commmand is supported}

    \PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dns\PYGZus{}test is a supported command}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\subsection{b1oph Usage}
\label{\detokenize{b1oph-usage:b1oph-usage}}\label{\detokenize{b1oph-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1oph}} provides generic calls to manage API calls for OPH
management. Additional ‘helper’ methods such as get\_ophid(), and the
ability to see the status of OPHs, Apps, and provide App control.

\subsection{b1platform Usage}
\label{\detokenize{b1platform-usage:b1platform-usage}}\label{\detokenize{b1platform-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{b1platform}} provides access to unsupported/undocumented plaform
specific API functions. These should therefore, only be used at the users
own risk. It should also be noted that these could change at any time.


\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{b1platform-usage:examples}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{\label{\detokenize{b1platform-usage:id1}}Todo:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These are simple examples to show you usage of the class. More comprehensive
documentation is on the todo.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{pprint} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{pprint}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Instantiate class with ini file as argument}
\PYG{n}{platform} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{b1platform}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZlt{}path to ini\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get current user details}
\PYG{n}{repsonse} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}current\PYGZus{}user}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get account membership for current user}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}current\PYGZus{}user\PYGZus{}accounts}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get current tenant name}
\PYG{n}{name} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}current\PYGZus{}tenant}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Get list of users}
\PYG{n}{response} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}users}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Retrieve the audit log}
\PYG{n}{audit\PYGZus{}log} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{auditlog}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Audit user accounts (uses domain of current user)}
\PYG{n}{list\PYGZus{}of\PYGZus{}non\PYGZus{}complient\PYGZus{}users} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{audit\PYGZus{}users}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Audit user accounts (provide list of domains)}
\PYG{n+nb}{list} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{platform}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{audit\PYGZus{}users}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{domains}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{infoblox.com}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{mydomain.com}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Additional Utilities}
\label{\detokenize{utils-usage:additional-utilities}}\label{\detokenize{utils-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{utils}} sub\sphinxhyphen{}module contains a set of data Utilities for data validation
and normalisation. Typically used for IoCs when using the {\hyperref[\detokenize{b1td-class:bloxone.b1td}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.b1td}}}}}
methods for searches against TIDE.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For performance purposes when handling bulk data, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data\_type()}},
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{validate\_fqdn()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{validata\_url()}} functions use pre\sphinxhyphen{}compliled
regexes that are created using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{buildregex()}} function, that returns
host and url regexes as a tuple.

\sphinxAtStartPar
These can then be passed to the appropriate data function.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{host\PYGZus{}regex}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{url\PYGZus{}regex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{utils}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{buildregex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{qdata} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my.host.name.com}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{utils}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{qdata}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{host\PYGZus{}regex}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{url\PYGZus{}regex}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Result = \PYGZsq{}host\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{qdata} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{http://my.host.name.com}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{utils}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{qdata}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{host\PYGZus{}regex}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{url\PYGZus{}regex}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Result = \PYGZsq{}url\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The remaining classes generally provide generic interfaces for \sphinxstyleemphasis{get}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{create}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{update} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{delete}.
Usage follows the same format of instantiating the class with an ini file and accessing the generic methods
using using the ‘swagger’ path for the appropriate object.

\section{b1platform Class}
\label{\detokenize{b1platform-class:b1platform-class}}\label{\detokenize{b1platform-class::doc}}\index{b1platform (class in bloxone)@\spxentry{b1platform}\spxextra{class in bloxone}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{b1platform-class:bloxone.b1platform}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{b1platform}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{cfg\_file}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}config.ini\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Class now reused for BloxOne Platform Methods, e.g. Audit Log
Management of BloxOne On Prem Hosts is via the b1oph Class
b1oph class  is inherited here for compatibility
\index{audit\_users() (bloxone.b1platform method)@\spxentry{audit\_users()}\spxextra{bloxone.b1platform method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\section{Usage and Examples for dhcputils (encode)}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_encode-usage:usage-and-examples-for-dhcputils-encode}}\label{\detokenize{dhcp_encode-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The DHCP Utils provides classes to assist with the encoding and decoding of
DHCP options in to/from hexidecimal. The primary use case is for sub\sphinxhyphen{}option
encoding for custom option spaces, in particular, Option 43 encoding.


\subsection{Encoding Class}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_encode-usage:encoding-class}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dhcp_encode-class:bloxone.dhcp_encode}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.dhcp\_encode()}}}}} class provides a set of \sphinxstyleemphasis{encode} methods
to enable the encoding of defined DHCP sub options and data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To encode the specific data\sphinxhyphen{}types a set of \sphinxstyleemphasis{type\_to\_hex} methods are provided.
These will take a specific input data=type and apply the required encoding
methodology to generate a compliant hexidecimal string for


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_encode-usage:usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The core aim of the class is to provide a simpler interface to encode DHCP sub
options defined as a dictionary and provide an encoding.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To ensure flexibility the encoding is broken down in to three methods:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{encode\_dhcp\_option()}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{encode\_sub\_option()}} and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{encode\_data()}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Sub\sphinxhyphen{}options are defined as a dictionary, with three required keys:
\begin{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{‘code’}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
the sub option code

\item[{‘type’}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
the data\sphinxhyphen{}type

\item[{‘data’}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
the data to encode using the specified type

\end{description}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
And several optional keys:
\begin{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{‘array’}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Boolean to indicate whether the data should be encoded as
an array, e.g. array of IP addresses

\item[{‘data\sphinxhyphen{}only’}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Boolen to indicate that only the data in the sub option should
be encoded. i.e. do not add the encoded option code and length

\end{description}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{sub1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{string}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ABCDEFG}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{sub2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ipv4\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
         \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10,10.11.11.11}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{array}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True} \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Since there is typically more that one sub\sphinxhyphen{}option required, these can be added
to a list that is processed, and encoded, by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{encode\_dhcp\_option()}}
method:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{options} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[} \PYG{n}{sub1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sub2} \PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
An example, with example output is shown below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}

\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}encode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Set up the sub\PYGZhy{}options}
\PYG{n}{sub1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{string}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ABCDEFG}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{sub2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ipv4\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
         \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10,10.11.11.11}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{array}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True} \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create list for option to be encoded together}
\PYG{n}{options} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[} \PYG{n}{sub1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sub2} \PYG{p}{]}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Encode e.g. for Option 43}
\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{encode\PYGZus{}dhcp\PYGZus{}option}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{h}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} print(h)}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{01074142434445464702080a0a0a0a0a0b0b0b}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Show the encoding for just one sub\PYGZhy{}option}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{encode\PYGZus{}sub\PYGZus{}option}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{sub2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} print(de.encode\PYGZus{}sub\PYGZus{}option(sub2))}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{02080a0a0a0a0a0b0b0b}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{test\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{101}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fqdn}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{www.example.com}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{encode\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{test\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} print(de.encode\PYGZus{}data(test\PYGZus{}data))}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{03777777076578616d706c6503636f6d00}
\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Return a list of supported data types:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}encode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opt\PYGZus{}types}
\PYG{g+go}{[\PYGZsq{}string\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv4\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv6\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}boolean\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int8\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint8\PYGZsq{},}
\PYG{g+go}{ \PYGZsq{}int16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}fqdn\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}binary\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}empty\PYGZsq{}]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each of the supported data\sphinxhyphen{}types has a specific method of the format
\sphinxstyleemphasis{type\_to\_hex()}. These can be directly access and typically support data both
in its native format and as a string:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{string\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Hello World}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ip4\PYGZus{}address\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{192.168.1.101}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fqdn\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{www.infoblox.com}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{int8\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{22}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{or} \PYG{n}{int8\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{22}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{etc}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Specific functions to return the length of the hexidecimal string in hex and
encoding of the option code (basically a wrapper of int8), are also provided:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ip4\PYGZus{}address\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{h}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{optcode\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}hex}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{125}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests()}} method is also provided that will show example encodings
for each data\sphinxhyphen{}type and option encodings:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}de.tests()}
\PYG{g+go}{Encoding types supported: [\PYGZsq{}string\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv4\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv6\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}boolean\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int8\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint8\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}fqdn\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}binary\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}empty\PYGZsq{}]}

\PYG{g+go}{Non\PYGZhy{}array tests:}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: string: AABBDDCCEEDD\PYGZhy{}aabbccddeeff, Encoded: 4141424244444343454544442d616162626363646465656666, Length(hex): 19}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: ipv4\PYGZus{}address: 10.10.10.10, Encoded: 0a0a0a0a, Length(hex): 04}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: ipv4\PYGZus{}address: 10.10.10.10,11.11.11.11, Encoded: 0a0a0a0a0b0b0b0b, Length(hex): 08}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: boolean: True, Encoded: 01, Length(hex): 01}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: int8: 22, Encoded: 16, Length(hex): 01}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: int8: \PYGZhy{}22, Encoded: 96, Length(hex): 01}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: uint8: 22, Encoded: 116, Length(hex): 01}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: int16: 33, Encoded: 0021, Length(hex): 02}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: int16: 33, Encoded: 0021, Length(hex): 02}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: uint16: 33, Encoded: 10021, Length(hex): 02}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: int32: 44, Encoded: 0000002c, Length(hex): 04}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: uint32: \PYGZhy{}44, Encoded: ffffffd4, Length(hex): 04}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: uint32: 44, Encoded: 10000002c, Length(hex): 04}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: fqdn: www.infoblox.com, Encoded: 0377777708696e666f626c6f7803636f6d00, Length(hex): 12}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: binary: DEADBEEF, Encoded: deadbeef, Length(hex): 04}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: empty: , Encoded: , Length(hex): 00}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: ipv6\PYGZus{}address: 2001:DB8::1, Encoded: 20010db8000000000000000000000001, Length(hex): 10}
\PYG{g+go}{Type: ipv6\PYGZus{}address: 2001:DB8::1,2001:DB8::2, Encoded: 20010db800000000000000000000000120010db8000000000000000000000002, Length(hex): 20}

\PYG{g+go}{Padding test (1 byte), type string: AABBCCDD 414142424343444400}
\PYG{g+go}{Full encoding of sample: 01194141424244444343454544442d61616262636364646565666602040a0a0a0a03080a0a0a0a0b0b0b0b040101050116}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\section{Usage and Examples for dhcputils (decode)}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_decode-usage:usage-and-examples-for-dhcputils-decode}}\label{\detokenize{dhcp_decode-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The DHCP Utils provides classes to assist with the encoding and decoding of
DHCP options in to/from hexidecimal. The primary use case is for sub\sphinxhyphen{}option
encoding for custom option spaces, in particular, Option 43 encoding.


\subsection{Decoding Class}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_decode-usage:decoding-class}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dhcp_decode-class:bloxone.dhcp_decode}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.dhcp\_decode()}}}}} class provides a set of \sphinxstyleemphasis{decode} methods
to attempt to decode a hexideciaml string representation of DHCP sub\sphinxhyphen{}options.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To decode specific data\sphinxhyphen{}types a set of \sphinxstyleemphasis{hex\_to\_type} methods are provided.
These take a hexideciaml string representation of the data and apply the
required decoding methodology and return the decoded data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Since and encoded set of DHCP sub\sphinxhyphen{}options does not include the data type
accurate decoding is problematic. Two mechanisms are provided to try and
address this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{It} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{n}{possible} \PYG{n}{to} \PYG{n}{provide} \PYG{n}{a} \PYG{n}{known} \PYG{n}{definition} \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{sub}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{options} \PYG{o+ow}{and}
\PYG{n}{use} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{specified} \PYG{n}{data} \PYG{n}{types}\PYG{o}{.}

\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{Allow} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{to} \PYG{n}{make} \PYG{n}{a} \PYG{n}{best}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{efforts} \PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{guess}\PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{of} \PYG{n}{the} \PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{.}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In both cases a string decoding is also applied and provided back. A flag,
\sphinxstyleemphasis{guess} is used to inform whether or not the data\_type was \sphinxstyleemphasis{guessed} or
based on a known definition.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DHCP\_OPTION\_DEFS}} class can be utilised to extract sub\sphinxhyphen{}option
definitions from a YAML configuration and maintain a vendor database of
option definitions.


\subsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp_decode-usage:usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The core aim of the class is to provide a simpler interface to decode DHCP sub
options and return this as a list of dictionary definitions detailing the
decoding.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To ensure flexibility the decoding is broken down in to two methods:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decode\_dhcp\_option()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decode\_data()}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decode\_data()}} takes the hexideciaml string and a data\_type and will
apply the appropriate hex\_to\_type() decoding method. For example:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}decode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{decode\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{0a0a0a0a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ipv4\PYGZus{}address}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Output: \PYGZsq{}10.10.10.10\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Note this can be shortened to}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} de.decode\PYGZus{}data(\PYGZsq{}0a0a0a0a\PYGZsq{}, data\PYGZus{}type=\PYGZsq{}ip\PYGZsq{})}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{decode\_dhcp\_option()}} also takes a hexidecimal string, however, in this
case it will be enterpreted as an encoded set of sub\sphinxhyphen{}options (based on option
43 encoding). As mentioned due to the fact that this does not contain data
type information, you can either provide a dictionary containing an option
definition (of the same format used by the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dhcp\_encode()}} class),
or let the function attempt to make a guess. In both cases the string decoding
will be included in the response.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The method returns a list of decoded sub\sphinxhyphen{}options with a dictionary per sub
option. This will be of the format:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
 \PYG{p}{[} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Undefined}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10,11.11.11.11}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{guess}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{array\PYGZus{}of\PYGZus{}ip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For simple output an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{output\_decoded\_options()}} method is provided.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}decode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Hex string to attempt to decode}
\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{01194141424244444343454544442d61616262636364646565666602040a0a0a0a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{+}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{03080a0a0a0a0b0b0b0b040101050116}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{opt\PYGZus{}list} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{decode\PYGZus{}dhcp\PYGZus{}option}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{h}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output\PYGZus{}decoded\PYGZus{}options}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{opt\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will produce the output:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{AABBDDCCEEDD\PYGZhy{}aabbccddeeff}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{25}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{AABBDDCCEEDD\PYGZhy{}aabbccddeeff}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{guess}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Undefined}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{string}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{guess}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Undefined}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{10.10.10.10,11.11.11.11}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{8}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x0b}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{guess}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Undefined}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{array\PYGZus{}of\PYGZus{}ip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x01}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{code}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{22}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}length}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data\PYGZus{}str}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}x16}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{guess}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Undefined}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{int8}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Example providing sub\sphinxhyphen{}option definitions using the same hex string:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\sphinxAtStartPar
As mentioned the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DHCP\_OPTION\_DEFS}} class can be utilised to access
vendor DHCP Option definitions from a YAML configuration an example script
and example vendor configuration file can be found as part of the
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/ccmarris/dhcp\_option\_encoding}{dhcp\_option\_encoding} project on GitHub.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A simple example using showing this is shown below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{h} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{010c4d532d55432d436c69656e740205687474707303196570736c}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{+}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{796e6330312e657073696c6f6e68712e6c6f63616c040334343305}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{+}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{252f4365727450726f762f4365727450726f766973696f6e696e67}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{+}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{536572766963652e737663}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{opt\PYGZus{}list} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{decode\PYGZus{}dhcp\PYGZus{}option}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{h}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sub\PYGZus{}opt\PYGZus{}defs}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{sub\PYGZus{}options}\PYG{p}{)}

\sphinxAtStartPar
As with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dhcp\_encode()}} class you can get a list of supported
decoding data types using the \sphinxstyleemphasis{opt\_types*} attribute:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}decode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{opt\PYGZus{}types}
\PYG{g+go}{[\PYGZsq{}string\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ip\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}array\PYGZus{}of\PYGZus{}ip\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv4\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}ipv6\PYGZus{}address\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}boolean\PYGZsq{},}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}int8\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint8\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint16\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}int32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}uint32\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}fqdn\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}binary\PYGZsq{},}
\PYG{g+go}{\PYGZsq{}empty\PYGZsq{}]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For decoding purposes the generic \sphinxstyleemphasis{ip} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{array\_of\_ip} types are exposed,
the respective methods support both IPv4 and IPv6.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each of the supported data\sphinxhyphen{}types has a specific method of the format
\sphinxstyleemphasis{hex\_to\_type()}. These can be directly access and typically support data both
in its native format and as a string:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}string}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{48656c6c6f20776f726c64}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZsq{}Hello world\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}ip}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{c0a80165}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZsq{}192.168.1.101\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}fqdn}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{0377777708696e666f626c6f7803636f6d00}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZsq{}www.infoblox.com.\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{n}{de}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{hex\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}int8}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{16}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} 22}

\PYG{n}{etc}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tests()}} method is also provided that will show example
encodings/decodings for each data\sphinxhyphen{}type and option encodings:

\section{DHCP Options Data Class Usage}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp-option-data-class-usage:dhcp-options-data-class-usage}}\label{\detokenize{dhcp-option-data-class-usage::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To simplify the definition and encoding/decoding of DHCP Options with the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dhcp_encode-class:bloxone.dhcp_encode}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.dhcp\_encode()}}}}} class, a data class to handle Vendor definitions
is included.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dhcp-option-data-class:bloxone.DHCP_OPTION_DEFS}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.DHCP\_OPTION\_DEFS()}}}}} class provides a simple interface to
read the vendor definition from a YAML file that can contain one or more
vendor definitions.


\subsection{YAML File Format}
\label{\detokenize{dhcp-option-data-class-usage:yaml-file-format}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The base file definition allows for a file version number and a list of
vendors, a sample showing all of the options is shown below:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} DHCP Vendor Option Definitions}
\PYG{n}{version}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.0}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

\PYG{n}{vendors}\PYG{p}{:}

    \PYG{n}{Sample}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Vendor}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{vci}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{sample}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{vci}
        \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{My} \PYG{n}{Vendor} \PYG{n}{Class}
        \PYG{n}{prefix}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZlt{}prefix str if required\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
        \PYG{n}{option}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{def}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{option}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{option} \PYG{n}{name}
                \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{43}
                \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{binary}
                \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
            \PYG{n}{sub}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Sub} \PYG{n}{Opt} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Encode} \PYG{n}{this} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{only}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Sub} \PYG{n}{Opt} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{ipv4\PYGZus{}address}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{10.10}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{10.10}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mf}{20.20}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{20.20}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{only}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The format allows the complete definition of a vendor, with the core element
being the \sphinxstyleemphasis{option\sphinxhyphen{}def} that defines, in particular, the list of sub\sphinxhyphen{}options
for encoding.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The definition can include a prefix to prepend to the encoding, and data\sphinxhyphen{}only
flags to handle both option 43 style encodings and option 125 style encodings.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Example Definitions:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} DHCP Vendor Option Definitions}
\PYG{n}{version}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{0.0}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}

\PYG{n}{vendors}\PYG{p}{:}

    \PYG{n}{MS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{UC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Client}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{vci}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{MS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{UC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Client}
        \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Microsoft} \PYG{n}{Lync} \PYG{n}{Client}
        \PYG{n}{option}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{def}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{option}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{option} \PYG{l+m+mi}{43}
                \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{43}
                \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{binary}
                \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
            \PYG{n}{sub}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{UC} \PYG{n}{Identifier}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{MS}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{UC}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Client}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{URL} \PYG{n}{Scheme}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{https}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Web} \PYG{n}{Server} \PYG{n}{FQDN}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{epslync01}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{epsilonhq}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{local}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Web} \PYG{n}{Server} \PYG{n}{Port}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{443}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Certificate} \PYG{n}{Web} \PYG{n}{Service}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{5}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{CertProv}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{CertProvisioningService}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{svc}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}


    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} CISCO}
    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Option 43 sub\PYGZhy{}option 241}

    \PYG{n}{Cisco} \PYG{n}{AP}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{vci}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Cisco} \PYG{n}{AP}
        \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Cisco} \PYG{n}{Aironet} \PYG{n}{Series} \PYG{n}{APs}
        \PYG{n}{option}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{def}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{option}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{option} \PYG{l+m+mi}{43}
                \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{43}
                \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{binary}
                \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
            \PYG{n}{sub}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Controller} \PYG{n}{IP}
                    \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{241}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{ipv4\PYGZus{}address}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mf}{10.150}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{1.15}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mf}{10.150}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{l+m+mf}{50.15}
                    \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}


    \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{} MITEL}

    \PYG{n}{Mitel}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{vci}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Mitel}
        \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Mitel} \PYG{n}{Phone} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{prepend} \PYG{l+m+mi}{00000403}\PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{n}{prefix}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{00000403}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
        \PYG{n}{option}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{def}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{parent}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{option}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{option} \PYG{l+m+mi}{125}
                \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{125}
                \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{binary}
                \PYG{n}{array}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{False}
            \PYG{n}{sub}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{options}\PYG{p}{:}
                \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{code}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{125}
                    \PYG{n+nb}{type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{string}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n+nb}{id}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n}{ipphone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mitel}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{p}{;}\PYG{n}{call\PYGZus{}srv}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{p}{;}\PYG{n}{vlan}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{p}{;}\PYG{n}{dscp}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{46}\PYG{p}{;}\PYG{n}{l2p}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{p}{;}\PYG{n}{sw\PYGZus{}tftp}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{X}
                    \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{only}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dhcp-option-data-class:bloxone.DHCP_OPTION_DEFS}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.DHCP\_OPTION\_DEFS()}}}}} class allows you to specify the YAML
file to read, and enables you to read the elements quickly and easily. As
an example, the file above can be used to encode the vendors sub\sphinxhyphen{}options:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{bloxone}
\PYG{n}{de} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{dhcp\PYGZus{}encode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{vendors} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{bloxone}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{DHCP\PYGZus{}OPTION\PYGZus{}DEFS}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{vendor\PYGZus{}dict.yaml}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\begin{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{Description:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Simple utility functions for data type validation, domain handling,
and data normalisationa specifically with the aim of supporting
queries to TIDE and Dossier.

\item[{Requirements:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Python3 with re, ipaddress, requests

\end{description}

\index{b1 (class in bloxone.bloxone)@\spxentry{b1}\spxextra{class in bloxone.bloxone}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{code:bloxone.bloxone.b1}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bloxone.bloxone.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{b1}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{cfg\_file}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}config.ini\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parent Class to simplify access to the BloxOne APIs for subclasses
Can also be used to genericallly access the API
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Raises}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
